citation.article-title: Klebsiella planticola sp. nov.: a new species of Enterobacteriaceae found primarily in nonclinical environments.

p.s: Description of Klebsiella planticola sp. nov.
Klebsiella planticola (plan.tid.o.la. M. L. fem.n. planta-a plant; L. suff. cola-dweller; M. L. fem.n. planticola-plant dweller)

Numerical taxonomy, mol% G+C, and DNA hybridization tests all indicate that Klebsiella planticola belongs as a new species within the genus Klebsiella. K. planticola mol% G+C base composition values are within the range reported for the genus: 52-59 mol% [4,9].
Both intragroup (79%) and intergroup (64-75%) phenetic similarities with other species of Klebsiella indicate the position of K. planticola as a separate species [7].
The numerical taxonomy data is confirmed by the fact that K. planticola strains had less than 50% RR to K. pneumoniae and K. oxytoca.
However, the average 79% RR of K. planticola strains when tested at the stringent temperature (Tm-10°C reveals genetic variation among the strains.
This is evidenced by the somewhat variable biochemical test results.
Phenotypically, K. planticola is most closely related to K. pneumoniae.
However, K. planticola
can be distinguished from both K. pneumoniae and K. oxytoca by a combination of biochemical tests (Table 3) [7,8].

Differentation between K. pneumoniae and K. planticola can be made on the basis of the fecal coliform test and growth at 10°C Previous studies have revealed both the ecological and sanitary significance of the fecal coliform reaction in the genus Klebsiella [2]; the present report illustrates that growth-temperature responses also have taxonomic significance.

For example, only 5 of 202 Klebsiella isolates from many sources did not conform to group placement based on reactions in the fecal coliform test, growth at 10~ indole production, and pectate degradation [8].
Only 1 K. pneumoniae strain did not produce gas from lactose fermentation at 44.5°C This culture is the neotype strain of K. pneumoniae, ATCC 13883.
In all other characteristics, including DNA reassociation, this strain conforms with other strains in the K. pneumoniae linkage group [7].
Although this strain is aberrant in the fecal coliform test, its lack of growth at 10°C provided a reassurance of the significance of the growth-temperature response for Klebsiella [8].

Indole-positive K. planticola can be distinguished from K. oxytoca by pectate degradation and utilization of gentisate and m-hydroxybenzoate. K. ozaenae and K. rhinoscleromatis can be distinguished from K. planticola, K. oxytoca, and K. pneumoniae because both of the former are positive on methyl red and negative on Voges-Proskauer tests [4,5].
In addition, K. rhinoscleromatis is anaerogenic on glucose and negative on Simmons' citrate and lysine decarboxylase.
Strains of K. ozaenae are generally negative on malonate and lysine decarboxylase and are often anaerogenic on glucose.

In an earlier numerical taxonomy study involving strains of Klebsiella, Gavini et al. [6] found a group of strains with biochemical characteristics similar to K. planticola (as described in this paper).
This group was designated as Class K or as strains having characteristics of both K. pneumoniae and K. oxytoca.
Strains in Class K were also largely of environmental origin (primarily aquatic), and only 3 of 25 strains were of direct human association (from feces).
As in the present studies, Gavini et al. found that the Class K Klebsiella did not ferment melezitose or dulcitol and did not use m-hydroxybenzoate.

The Class K isolates did not grow at 44.5°C about 50% grew at 4°C K. planticola did not ferment lactose at 44.5°C but grew at 10°C Indole was produced by 54% of the Class K isolates, whereas only 15% of the K. planticola were indole positive and only some of the biogroup 1 strains exhibited this trait.

K. planticola can also be differentiated from K. pneumoniae and K. oxytoca based on habitat of origin, as most K. planticola (about 95%) have been isolated from plant-associated and aquatic environments [3,7,8,9].

The general lack of antibiotic resistance (other than to ampicillin) is characteristic of organisms of this environmental origin [11]. K. planticola strains have been found in wastewater, although few isolates were associated with cases of human and animal disease [7,8], and the two multiply-antibiotic-resistant strains in this study were of human and animal origin.
Clinical bacteriologists would, however, identify most of these strains as K. pneumoniae owing to the fact that fecal coliform and growth at 10°C tests are not performed routinely [4].
If indole positive, strains might be identified as K. oxytoca owing to the lack of pectate degradation tests.
Further studies should therefore be conducted to determine the environmental, human, and animal distribution and importance of K. planticola.
The name Klebsiella planticola is proposed for this organism.
This species name was chosen to indicate the typical plant-associated habitat of origin for the majority of the strains.
Strain V-236 (ATCC 33531, CDC 4245-72) is designated as the type strain of this species.
As planta can be loosely translated as "an edible vegetable" [10], planticola also signifies the vegetable (i.e., radish) origin of the type strain [3].
